results.title: Sir John Cockroft
results.creator_credit: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and British Information Services
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Commonwealth Teleview”.
Sir John Cockcroft, Director of Britain’s Atomic Research Establishment, answers question, put to him by Robert McKenzie, about construction and operation of the Calder Hall nuclear power station and the establishment of the Canadian Atomic Research Center at Chalk River. He talks about the far-reaching effects of Britain’s atomic power program on the everyday life of Britain and the Commonwealth whilst also making it clear that nuclear power is always more expensive - up to 10 times more - than fossil fuels. Closes with live footage of the Queen’s opening speech at Calder Hall.

results.title: New town
results.creator_credit: British Information Services and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Commonwealth Teleview”.
Commonwealth Teleview Series - Visiting Harlow, a British satellite town, Christopher Chataway discusses this ‘modern’ building phenomenon with Frederick Gibberd, the city’s architect-planner. Chataway also interviews people living and working in the town, obtaining their views on this experiment in town planning.

results.title: The Commonwealth to the Commonwealth: Dr. Nkrumah
results.creator_credit: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and British Information Services
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Commonwealth Teleview”.
In this filmed interview marking the occasion of Ghana’s independence, Dr Kwame Nkrumah, Ghana’s first Prime Minister, answers questions put to him by Robert McKenzie about the nation’s political, economic and social achievements of the past and the present, and talks about this people’s hopes and aspirations for the future.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and British Information Services

results.title: Sir Robert Scott
results.creator_credit: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and British Information Services
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Commonwealth Teleview”.
Interviewed by Matthew Halton, Sir Robert Scott discusses his work as Britain’s Commissioner-General for South-East Asia. He talks about the importance of the area in Commonwealth and world affairs and some of the forces at work there such as SEATO (South East Asia Treaty Organisation) and the Colombo Plan.

results.title: The Commonwealth to the Commonwealth: Prince Philip's tour 1956
results.creator_credit: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and British Information Services
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Commonwealth Teleview”.
The world tour of HRH Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, as described by him on his return during a film and lantern-slide lecture of tour material shown to schoolchildren in London’s Royal Festival Hall. Shows inspection of British survey bases in Antarctica, a visit to a factory whaling ship, to islands in the South Atlantic, to Gambia, Malaya, New Guinea and Australia.

results.title: Road to independence
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Balla, Ronald Dick and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “The Commonwealth of Nations”.
There is world-wide significance in the planned process by which Britain is helping her colonies master the art of self-government. This concluding film cites recent developments in Ghana, Nigeria, Nyasaland and other colonial territories where political evolution has seen striking progress in recent years. Edgar McInnis analyzes these developments on the basis of two main considerations; and why a ruling power should arrange for its own departure from its colonies; why, once independent, the former subjects should continue to associate with their former master.

results.title: The Colonies look ahead
results.creator_credit: John Howe, Ronald Dick and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “The Commonwealth of Nations”.
A film survey of economic development, education and race relations in various British colonial territories. Progress in representative colonies, such as Kenya, is assessed on the basis of their ability to manage their own affairs and to achieve self-government. Narrated by Edgar McInnis.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Howe, Ronald Dick and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: They called it white man's burden
results.creator_credit: Ronald Dick and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “The Commonwealth of Nations”
Paternalism, with all its problems and achievements among colonial peoples, has a tradition within the Commonwealth which is often misunderstood. This film suggests that the stereotyped picture many people have of colonial officialdom needs revising in the light of Britain’s record. The “Great White Father,” we see, although not oblivious to the material advantages a colony could provide, brought with him, more often than not, a deep sense of responsibility for the welfare of people under his jurisdiction. Noteworthy are campaigns to improve agriculture, alleviate suffering, raise living standards and promote literacy.

results.title: Colonialism: ogre or angel?
results.creator_credit: Ronald Dick and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “The Commonwealth of Nations”.
How the British colonial empire grew is a story as full of adventure as it is of contrast. This film takes us to British colonies, protectorates and protected states to see the impact of industrialization on colonial people, and their awakening desire for self-determination. Narrated by Edgar McInnis.
